Award.AwardTitle: BREAD: Basic Mechanisms Underlying Species-Specific Trypanosome Resistance
Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Jayne Raper (Hunter College of the City of New York University)

CoPIs: Jose Cibelli (Michigan State University); Alan Archibald (University of Edinburgh); Steve Kemp, International Livestock Research Institute (ILRI) (Nairobi, Kenya)

Collaborators: Aris Economides (Regeneron Pharmaceuticals); Bruce Whitelaw (University of Edinburgh)

Trypanosomiasis affects cattle and is prevalent in 36 countries of sub-Saharan Africa. It is caused by parasites of the Trypanosoma species, which are transmitted by tsetse flies. Infection with these parasites invariably leads to death. In addition cattle are reservoirs for trypanosomes that infect humans and thereby cause an increase in disease transmission resulting in human sleeping sickness, which is also fatal. Baboons are naturally resistant to all these pathogens due to a factor in their blood known as trypanosome lytic factor, which is a form of High-Density Lipoprotein (the "good" cholesterol). A single baboon gene has been identified that when given transiently to mice by gene therapy (as mice do not have this gene), completely protects them from infection with trypanosomes. The goal of this research project is to determine if the mechanism of species-specific trypanosome resistance characterized in primates is shared by other vertebrates, such as cattle.

Broader Impacts: Trypanosomiasis is arguably one of the most significant diseases to threaten livestock production in infected areas of the world. The animal disease causes immense human suffering due to the reduction of milk and meat production by approximately 50%, as well as the lack of haulage for crop production, which are central to most African small scale agriculture. Accordingly, trypanosomiasis is ranked among the top 10 global cattle diseases impacting on the poor, and estimates of the cost of the disease to livestock keepers and consumers vary between $1 to 5 billion US dollars annually. This research project could lead to improved sustainability of livestock production in a broad region of the developing world. Drugs that kill trypanosomes have been extensively used in animals (35 million doses/year), but drug resistance and disease resurgence has been reported in at least 13 countries. If this basic research project could demonstrate the proof of principle that cattle with the baboon gene have complete protection from all pathogenic African trypanosomes, including human infective trypanosomes, it could have a strong long term impact in that it could lead to the elimination of an important reservoir that drives human infection. Public access to data and biological materials generated by this research project will be available through a project wiki - http://www.genomics.liv.ac.uk/tryps/index.php.

POR.DRECONTENT:
BENEFITS TO SOCIETY - Our goal, that delivers benefits to society, was to confer resistance to a deadly disease, trypanosomiasis,  that kills people and cattle in Africa. The animal disease causes immense human suffering due to the reduction of milk and meat production by ~50%, as well as the lack of haulage for crop production, which are central to most African small-scale agriculture. Accordingly, trypanosomiasis is ranked among the top ten global cattle diseases impacting on the poor, and estimates of the cost of the disease to livestock farmers and consumers vary between US$1 and 5 billion annually.  Critically, the ownership of livestock also has many intangible benefits: it increases the resilience of resource-poor communities towards adversity.

African trypanosomiasis in cattle is prevalent in 36 countries of sub-Saharan Africa. It is caused by parasites of the Trypanosoma species, which are transmitted by tsetse ﬂies and tabanids. Infection with these parasites invariably leads to death. Cattle are also reservoirs for trypanosomes that infect humans resulting in human ?sleeping sickness?, which is also fatal.  The World Health Organisation (WHO) has targeted Human African Trypanosomiasis for eradication, and significant progress has been made towards achieving this goal.

BROADER IMPACT - Since trypanosomiasis is arguably one of the most significant diseases to threaten livestock production in infected areas, we organised workshops and spoke about our research at three meetings in Central, West and East Africa and the US (United States Department of Agriculture) to build trust and gain public acceptance of new technology to the broadest range of diverse stakeholders, In Kenya the focus was to speak to small holder farmers, pastoralists, policy makers, regulators, wildlife managers and a wide range of scientists in livestock genetics, breeding, animal health and animal husbandry. We communicated research and its outputs to encourage uptake via ?Translating from Genetic Research in Africa to Adoption and Social Value.?

The New Partnership for Africa's Development (NEPAD) African Biosafety Network of Expertise (ABNE) and National Biosafety Authorities have the mandate to assist in the development of regulations that allow harnessing technological advances while minimising potential risks.  In response to our research, in Kenya the National Biosafety Authority created a guideline ?Guidelines for Regulation of Genetically Modified Animals Under Containment in Kenya?, 2018.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT - To access expertise the research team was an international collaboration between scientists in the US, UK and Kenya.  During the project we established the first mammalian gene transfer facility in Sub-Saharan Africa at the International Livestock Research Institute. 

Over five years there has been a large amount of training and professional development of people ranging from scientists (post-graduate, graduate and undergraduate), technicians, veterinarians to small holders, farmers and regulatory officials.  Our scientists have presented our findings at globally at academic conferences in Africa, Europe and the US.  The scientific results are published in the academic literature and one TEDx talk is online.

RESEARCH OUTPUTS - A sustainable approach to controlling trypanosomiasis is to develop cattle breeds able to resist infection. Drugs that kill trypanosomes have been extensively used in animals (35 million doses/year), but drug resistance and disease resurgence has been reported in at least 13 countries.

Alternatively, some primates  have resistance to trypanosomes, provided by a protein, APOLIPOPROTEIN L1 (APOL1, which is found in a complex called the Trypanosome Lytic Factor (TLF) that circulates in the blood as part of ?good? cholesterol.  We created synthetic versions of the APOL1 gene that were introduced into a specific site into the DNA of mice. This approach was shown to provide full resistance against trypanosomes in mice that were given the synthetic APOL1 gene.

Based on this finding, we posited that cattle that have the synthetic APOL1 gene should also have complete protection from all pathogenic African trypanosomes, including human infective trypanosomes, which would also eliminate an important reservoir that drives human infection. We are introducing the synthetic APOL1 sequence into a specific site in the DNA of Boran African cattle. This genetic disease-resistance should improve the sustainability of livestock production in a broad region of the developing world. 

SUMMARY - It is now potentially possible to provide complete protection to African livestock from all pathogenic African trypanosomes, which should also eliminate an important reservoir that drives human infection. This constitutes an innovative approach using genetic modification to create disease-resistance and improve the sustainability of livestock production in a broad region of the developing world with the associated biosafety regulatory frameworks.
